title.narrative: CLACSO Knowledge for a Sustainable World 2013-2018
CLACSO Kunskap för en hållbar värld 2013-2018

description.narrative: Program support to the Latin American Council for Social Sciences (CLACSO). The Council works with competitive research grants, regional thematic working groups, postgraduate courses, relations to the public sector and the civil society, publication and dissemination of research results etc.

Programstöd till det Latinamerikanska forskningsrådet för samhällsvetenskaper (CLACSO). Rådet arbetar med konkurrensutsatta forskningsstöd, regionala tematiska forskargrupper, forskarutbildningskurser, relationer till offentliga sektorn och civila samhället, publicering och spridning av forskningsresultat etc.

title.narrative: Grant Agreement between Sida and CLACSO July 2018 - June 2021

description.narrative: The Latin American Council of Social Sciences (CLACSO) is a non-governmental international institution established in 1967 to promote research in social science and humanities. The Council counts 623 research centres and graduate schools affiliated, in 48 countries, primarily Latin American countries. Between 2000 - 2012 CLACSO received direct support from Sida in the form of core funding, including all CLACSO programmes (except the CROP Programme which was financed by Norway). A shift to program support was done for the last period 2013-2018 (including the extension period). The present agreement 2013-2018 has reached a total of 60. 600 000 SEK. The last decision on support (2013) for the period of 2013 - 2017 was followed by a decision on extension ( June 2017 - June 2018). Although CLACSO has partnership with CONACIT, CLATE, Oxfam and Ford Foundation Sida remains CLACSO´s largest budget contributor. However, in 2011 Sida funds covered approximately 80 percent of CLACSO's activities, while today the Sida contribution amounts to some 30 percent of the total budget. CLACSO´s membership network has expanded during the last 6 years from 312 institutions to 623 by the end of 2017. It still holds a strong Latin America and Caribbean (LAC) region perspective while it aims to increase North-South and especially South-South collaboration. Such work is carried out by post grad courses and summer schools as well as Working Groups (available at CLACSO´ website). Some WG have members from associated centres outside LAC region. In 2017 an evaluation was commissioned by Sida to better understand the relevance of CLACSO´s work in relation to the Research cooperation strategy (2015-2021), its effectiveness, efficiency and sustainability. It also aims to inform the future partnership between CLACSO and Sida. Results and recommendations are expected to support discussions for a next phase of support. Overall the evaluation states that CLACSO´ objectives have clear and explicit alignment with the objectives 2 and 3 of the research cooperation strategy. It points out that CLACSO has achieved “a very substantial level of results by an emphasis on maintaining relevance to both its members and in relation to the social, economic and cultural challenges faced in the region.” The evaluation states that CLACSOs efficiency and sustainability are supported by the ownership of their members. Its relevance is guided by both the interest of the members as well as the pollical and economic scenario of the LAC region. The evaluation also concludes that: “CLACSO´s research looks at the need for innovative policies that can overcome the profound structural factors – including power, violence and gender/ethnic exclusion – that prevent poor and marginalised populations from reaping the benefits from their products and services. The evaluation has found how CLACSO has lined with social movements, policy makers, journalists and other actors in “innovation systems” that reflect overall objectives of Swedish development cooperation related to human rights, discrimination and addressing the root causes of conflict. CLACSO focuses on these Swedish priorities in a manner reflects and derives from the ethical commitments and priorities from its members" (executive summary, page 6). Therefore, the evaluation “judges that these qualities are well-aligned with Swedish policies for research cooperation, even if CLACSO is a somewhat unconventional network in comparison to other more purely academic networks among the programmes that Sida supports" (page 7).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
